characters: ON CHUBBY, PONYTAIL AND CARRIER NAMED DREW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jagged mountains defy a dark, foreboding sky. We hear PLODDING HOOVES, CREAKING LEATHER. A lone wanderer appears. Wearing a long coat and a battered hat, he carries a bolt-action carbine. His name forgotten, history remembers him simply as THE POSTMAN. His laden pack mule, BILL, BRAYS, as they pass a battered sign: "The Great Salt Lake Marina." They start down a slope and begin to cross a...

dialogues.speaker: DRY LAKE BED
dialogues.text: A bizarre, wind-swept sight. Dozens of boats resting lee- to on the dry, cracked earth. It's like God pulled the plug. Rusty mooring chains snake their way around house boats, ski boats and a cabin cruiser or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last of the great cities died when my father was a child. Another victim of yet another war. The plagues followed. And the terrors. The living hid themselves away in tiny hamlets in hopes of surviving whatever new madness conspired to rob them of the little that remained. The Earth itself had fallen prey to chaos. For three years a dirty snow fell that even summer could not erase. The ocean was barren. Poisoned. Near death. As The Postman continues to cross, the CAMERA PULLS BACK. He's soon lost in the massive vista.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixteen long years passed before the great lungs started working again. My father said it was as if the ocean breathed a great sigh of relief... A RUMBLE of THUNDER. RAIN begins to fall. The earth just sucks it up at first, but it's coming hard. Rivulets run. Puddles form. We begin to get the feeling that soon these boats will be tugging at the mooring chains once again.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TRACK a rivulet as it runs, filling up a depression in th sand. And then, running to fill another in a series of depressions. They make a pattern we recognize as --

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S FOOTPRINTS
dialogues.text: These tracks may already be days old as they fill with rain water. Then, the sound of light, padded FOOTFALLS. A LION ENTERS FRAME. Lean, hungry and dangerous, the big cat has been tracking this man. He lets out a low, disappointed GROWL. The rain has foiled his dinner plans -- for now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bullet-ridden sign reads: "U.S. 84 North." The Postman leads Bill down a barren 4-lane. Weeds poke up through the asphalt. The rusting hulk of a car rests in the median, covered in a tangle of purple wisteria. The Postman plucks a flower. He sticks it into a buttonhole and continues. BILL BRAYS woefully.    In answer:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. And if you ask me again, I'm going to slug you. They near a sign: "Thank You For Visiting Utah." The Postman waves, shouts to the sign as he passes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been fun, hasn't it, kids? (to the sign)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill tugs up weeds as The Postman is climbing up a ladder on a highway that razor cuts the plains to the horizon. Above, The Postman sands atop a billboard catwalk. He references a tattered road atlas, scans the horizon through binoculars with one broken lens. He pauses at a Union 76 ball just visible above the tree line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A 76 Station and the remains of a Howard Johnson's. Alert, carbine in hand, The Postman leads in the mule. Rusting cars sag on flattened tires. There's a stripped fire engine, its cracked hoses leading to the HoJo foundation which bristles with burned timbers. Bill stops to drink out of a stream.   The Postman swats him with his hat. THE POSTMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnit, Bill, you know I need to check it first! Bill hangs his head. The Postman digs through his pack. He removes an old Tupperware container and replaces its contents -- a tiny sheaf of litmus papers and several small bottles -- with stream water. He adds a few drops from each bottle. Swirls it around. Then dips a tiny strip of paper into the water. The paper turns a vivid purple. The Postman is dubious. THE POSTMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better than turpentine. (touches some to his lips)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tastes about the same. Your call, Bill. Bill drinks. THE POSTMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't picky, Bill. I like that about you. The Postman takes his carbine and a burlap sack and crosses to the 76 Station. An old extension ladder on the ground. The pole holding up the 76 ball has a 30-degree bend in it, like someone once tried to pull it over. Beyond the 76 ball, the sun sets -- but we here in the 20th Century have never seen such a wild riot of color before. The Postman tries the station door. Locked. Smiling ironically, he steps in through the blown-out window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shambles. The Postman kicks around the table. He finds a few beat-up CDs, flips through them. Reads the label.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Running on Empty'? Tell me about it. Tossing it, he turns, stops. There, resting on a pile of trash is a bashed-in portable TV. The Postman smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Bill! We got TV! 147 channels. Everything from Jesus to 'Jeopardy'. He steps over, switches on the set.      Nothing happens, The Postman pretends just the same.      He mimics static then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Like sands through the hour- glass, so are the days of our lives...' (switching channels)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Michael Shields, come on down, you're the next contestant on...'The Price is Right'.' (switching again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take Domestic Nuclear Disasters for two hundred thousand, Alex... The Postman stops suddenly.    Click.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We interrupt our regularly scheduled program to bring you the Second Civil War... Well, shit. The Postman stares at the blank screen a moment. There's a sudden, panicked RUSTLING from behind the service manager's desk. The Postman wheels around, raises the carbine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want any trouble... I bet you don't either... Let's just call it a draw, okay? Sudden MOVEMENT. The Postman shouts in surprise as a Doe dashes out from behind the desk. Scared, it bounds back and forth between the walls. Then freezes in the corner. The Postman sighs in relief, lowers the carbine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look out, Bill!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The doe bolts for the window and runs right into Bill. Bill has a conniption fit. Investigating further, The Postman spots a cigarette machine. The front glass is smashed and all the slots are empty. But he looks down to the lock at the bottom. It's intact. He pulls a crowbar from the sack, crouches by the machine and digs the pry into a seam and pulls. The panel bursts open to reveal four half-open cartons of cigarettes. He doesn't believe it for a second. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm rich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Embers of a campfire glow.    The Postman is asleep, the carbine in reach. BILL BRAYS and nervously stamps his hooves. The Postman reaches for the carbine only to find the barrel of a shotgun pointed in his face. Three BANDITS! Hard-eyed and ugly. One, barely 20, is mostly just ugly. The Postman looks down the barrels of a shotgun, a rifle and a revolver. The LEAD BANDIT kicks the carbine out of reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just passing through. I don't mean anyone any harm. (re: stream)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water's good. The Lead Bandit pokes at The Postman's shoulder with the muzzle of his rifle. The Postman knows why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a Holnist. The Lead Bandit pokes again. Harder. The Postman opens his shirt, reveals his bare left shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay? They just stare at him, none saying a word.      Creepy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm headed for a town called St. Rose. Somewhere west of Portland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Portland's under twenty feet of water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I heard different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mouthin' me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's just that it's hard to get good information. The third BANDIT, a HULKING brute, has been quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is mouthin' you; I say we kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be in such a rush, Martin. (back to The Postman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I see a pack mule over there, but I don't see no packs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all I got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Kill him, Martin. The Hulking Bandit, raises his shotgun. The butt end. He's going to bludgeon The Postman to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay!   My stuff's up there! The 76 ball is twenty feet above the ground. In the gloom you can just see a hole has been punched through the side

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you got in there? The Lead Bandit swats Bandit #20 upside the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. (to Postman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you got in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dried peas.   Beef jerky. Cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarettes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.   There's the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's got it booby-trapped. The Lead Bandit is about to smack Bandit #20 again -- the he sees the logic out of it. The Postman shakes his head, but isn't that convincing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go up and get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladder set against the bent pole. Prodded by a shotgun, The Postman climbs, disappears through the hole and into the tilting 76 ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full of The Postman's earthly possessions. Trick is, how to save them and his life at the same time. He spies an old wrench: remnant of an attempt to remove the rusty bolts holding the ball in place. An idea begins to take shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just you start tossing those cigarettes down!

dialogues.speaker: BANDITS
dialogues.text: There's no answer.     The Bandits eye each other nervous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he fell asleep.

dialogues.speaker: BALL
dialogues.text: The Postman grabs the wrench, starts working one of the last two rusted bolts. As it starts to give...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to take a second.    I got my stuff bolted in.

dialogues.speaker: BANDITS
dialogues.text: The Lead Bandit takes a cautious step back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put some buckshot through it, Martin. Just to hurry him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only got three shells left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So use his gun. The Hulking Bandit picks up the carbine and aims. CLICK. It isn't loaded. The Hulking Bandit tosses the gun aside, pulls a knife from his boot. Grimly, he begins to climb.

dialogues.speaker: BALL
dialogues.text: Cramped, The Postman's busy at the base of the ball, trying to unscrew the last remaining bolt. It won't budge.

dialogues.speaker: LADDER
dialogues.text: The Hulking Bandit has only a few more rungs to go.

dialogues.speaker: BALL
dialogues.text: No good.   Time's up.   The Postman starts rocking the po

dialogues.speaker: LADDER
dialogues.text: The Hulking Bandit has reached the opening -- feels the rocking motion. Hangs on.

dialogues.speaker: BALL
dialogues.text: Knife in hand, the Hulking Bandit looks inside. At that instant, The Postman rocks the pole one more time. The rusty bolt is not enough to keep the ball's full weight i place. It pops. The ball is frozen for an instant before going with the pole's tilt.

dialogues.speaker: LADDER
dialogues.text: The 76 ball drops off the pole, rolling over the Hulking Bandit's back and down the ladder's incline. The other Bandits dive clear as the 76 ball hurtles past.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: whips head over heels as the ball speeds away.

dialogues.speaker: FIELD
dialogues.text: The 76 ball launches off a dirt berm, but soon comes to a stop as it slams into an old utility pole and bursts apart. Fighting the vertigo, The Postman staggers to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill! Bill bolts from the station as the Lead Bandit raises the RIFLE and FIRES at The Postman. Losing balance, The Postman lands on his butt just before a bullet splinters the utility pole above his head. Wobbly, he tries to gather his packs. The Bandits charge, quickly closing the ground, but Bill is there first. Holding as much as he can, The Postman heaves himself ove Bill's back. As the mule gallops away, the Lead Bandit aims the rifle. He's got The Postman in his sights. He's about to fire when -- Bandit #20 stands up INTO the SHOT. He's got a fistful of cigarettes in each hand and he's laughing like a hyena!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're rich!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman sits on a rock, holding Bill's halter so the mule must face him. They are in the midst of an argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true, we haven't done this in a while, but it's like riding a bicycle. Now, open your mouth. The Postman pries his mouth open. Taking a toothbrush, he tends to Bill's teeth, then gives him an appraising look. BILL BRAYS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the rule. It's my rule! Avoid civilization at all costs. But we gotta eat, don't we? (as BILL BRAYS again)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you so worried about, Bill? All you gotta do is stand there. I'm the one with all the lines. The Postman leads the mule down the hill toward the town far below. Making his case all the while -- even as BILL BRAYS in protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A patch of mud. In the center of the square fifty townspeople stand before a plank stage where The Postman wraps up a performance of MacBeth. He plays it with a mis-remembered gusto the people enjoy. Children especially are enamored. A heavily-muscled man, WOODY, lingers on the fringe of the crowd -- watching The Postma with inscrutable intensity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said, 'Fear not, MacBeth, 'til Birnam Wood comes to Dunsinane'! He looks off stage for someone, but no one appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, Birnam Wood comes to Dunsinane! Bill trots on-stage. Covered with twigs, BILL is Birnam Wood. He BRAYS lustily. The audience laughs in delight. The children clap. Only Woody seems unaffected.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Postman grabs two wooden swords -- he knows it's goin well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arm, arm yourselves! If the witch's words are true, there'll be no running or hiding here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaking off the twigs, Bill takes one of the swords in hi mouth. The two of them dash back and forth pretending to fight off an imaginary attack. Finally, The Postman looks out at the audience, remembers the words the best he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, and tomorrow, and the day after that. Out brief candle! Life's but a walking shadow, a poor player that struts his hour upon the stage and is heard no more. It's a tale told by a moron. Full of sound and fury, signifying nothing. (waves sword) But blow, wind! Come wrack! At least we'll die with the harness off our back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The audience erupts in applause. But Woody stands still as stone. The Postman takes a bow. Even Bill does a cross-legged dip. Knowing when to quit, he steps off the stage to many hearty handshakes. Woody watches his every move. MRS. THOMPSON, one of the town's leaders, steps up. She's accompanied by crotchety old CURMUDGEON LARRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children have never heard Shakespeare before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) They still haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Curmudgeon is still clapping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.   You're very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm clapping because you stink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you understand how it works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was young, I tried to be an actor. I was awful. But now I won't die thinking I was the worst one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad I could help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry, stop it. (to The Postman) You were very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good enough to get something to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before she can answer, a SENTRY cries...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holnists!   Holnists are coming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All eyes look down the road leading into town. A raiding party of Holnist Cavalry are on their way in. Mrs. Thompson sees The Postman's concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. We give them food and supplies. All the towns do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hardly kill anyone lately. Just take a woman sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd just as soon not give them anything of mine. Let's find the back door, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman gathers his stuff, slings packs onto Bill. The forty Holnists in orange and black uniforms ride in. They're armed with mostly pistols and rifles. Some carry bows, knives, spear guns and swords. On their bare shoulders, branded into the flesh -- the number "8."

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Out front, always leading by example is, GENERAL BETHLEHEM. Tough, smart, merciless with style. Commander of the United Clans of Holn. Nothing escapes his eye. A little behind him is the mysteriously silent Colonel Getty, second in command. The Postman, finished packing, begins to move from building to building -- careful not to attract any attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman freezes, turns, is relieved to find Bethlehem's not talking to him at all. The General looks down from his horse at children playing an impromptu game of "Birnam Wood." The children stop, stare at their feet. Bethlehem affects a "kindly" smile to accompany his gentler tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meantime, The Postman continues his surreptitious escape. The MAYOR hurries forward to greet Bethlehem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a game, General Bethlehem. Something they saw in a play. No harm in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A play? (to kids) Show me. It's all right, children, show me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One BRAVE BOY finds his voice, barely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arm, arm yourselves! No running from the witches!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Shakespeare, is it? Well, I'm sorry I missed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should know, sir, we haven't nearly stocked the game we thought we would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?   But you had time for a play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Head down, The Postman makes for "the back way." But it's guarded by three daunting Holnist soldiers. No getting by them. The Postman does a quick 180, goes back the way he came. Bethlehem looks at the frightened townsfolk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm taking three conscripts from each town. They will have the honor of serving in the Holnist Army until such time as I see fit. (to Mayor) Three men. You suppose you could do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor nods in acquiescence. Bethlehem looks to a Holnist officer. The officer, IDAHO, steps up and addresses the town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All men between 15 and 50 and of suitable ethnic foundation are required to show themselves now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Holnist soldiers fan out, prodding any likely or unwilling candidates forward. The Postman is now walking behind Bethlehem. Some of the Townspeople cast him a furtive glance as he makes his way toward the open courtyard and, ultimately, the gate out o town. Three conscripts are hustled before Bethlehem. He looks over the first -- Woody. Smells him. Not much of a decision here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acceptable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acceptable, Captain!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The second -- a thin teenager. Bethlehem feels his arm, turns his head from side to side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll need to put some meat on, but I like an impressionable mind. Acceptable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The third -- an innocuous man. Or so we think. Bethlehem stares hard at his olive skin, traces a finger over the bump on the man's nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mongoloid.   Unacceptable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldiers shove the man back into the crowd. The Brave Boy that was playing Birnam Wood allows himself a tiny smile when he sees that The Postman might make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want pure blood. Someone like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem notes the Boy, turns to see the object of his attention, and spots The Postman leaving out the front gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Idaho and another soldier are on it. The Postman tries to back away as the two dismount and come toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Idaho and the soldier aren't programmed for explanations -- they grab him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were required to show yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, I'm not with these people. I'm just passing through. I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Idaho silences him with a rifle butt to the head. Everything falls OUT OF FOCUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the mule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spread out in the valley is General Bethlehem's Holnist Expeditionary Force. A five hundred-man army enjoying all the comforts a bivouac can offer. 19 head-shaved CONSCRIPTS, including Woody and The Postman, are held in a cramped, barbed wired pen. They watch as three more are shoved inside. One of them is Bandit #20. He and The Postman come face to face, recognize each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astonished)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi? The Postman steps toward him, Bandit #20 backs off quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I mean, we know each other, kind of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what did you guys do with my cigarettes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We traded them for a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful.   What happened to your partners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They traded me to the Holnists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten hut! General Bethlehem approaches on horseback. Colonel Getty follows behind. Bethlehem looks his new recruits over. Dismounting, he enters the pen and walks among them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome, gentlemen, to your new life. You have been born again as soldiers in the army of the United Clans of Holn. The strong have been sapped by the whimpering propaganda of the weak. Men, strong men, have been denied their destiny. You men have been saved from that fate. Redemption is within your grasp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts down the line, looking the men over. He stops in front of a GANGLY RECRUIT. The Postman is alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. What did you do before you were given this opportunity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a shovel. I digged holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem regards him benevolently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You digged holes... Well, now you're going to fill them. (turns to Postman) And you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any question in anyone's mind that I was talking to you? Yes, you. You look like a dangerous man. Are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just a performer. Shakespeare. Stuff like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a writer. He --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who Shakespeare was... 'Cry "Havoc!" and let slip the dogs of war.'

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bethlehem says the lines boldly, encourages his men to clap for him. He looks at The Postman expectantly. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, um, you want a line?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem nods.     The Postman thinks a moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'To be or not to be: That is the question.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem looks at his men as if to say, "Is this all thi guy's got?" Bethlehem eyes The Postman; he wants a contest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'We few, we happy few, we band of brothers.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Holnists clap, they know their General can best this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gaining confidence) 'Now is the winter of our discontent made glorious summer by this son of York.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem claps The Postman on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pretty good. You're also a fighter. I see it in your eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman doesn't answer. Hesitant, he doesn't want to get into any more trouble than he's already in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you agree? Come on, a man's got to speak his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem sounds sincere.    He seems like a good guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean any disrespect, sir, but you'd be better off just letting me go. A fighter is about the last thing I am.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Postman doubles over as Bethlehem hooks a fist into his gut. Bethlehem clubs him in the head, dropping him to his knees, then digs a boot into his side. The Postman goes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think I should be the judge of that, soldier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman gasps to catch his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up.   I said, get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman staggers to his feet. Blood trickles from his nose as he stares across at Bethlehem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put up your fists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem looks to Getty. CLICK. Getty shoves a PISTOL is into The Postman's ear. The Postman reluctantly raises his fists. Bethlehem gives him a satisfied nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman takes a tentative step forward. Bethlehem drives him back with a flurry of blows. The Postman is dazed, nearly out on his feet. Bethlehem holds him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. You're not a fighter. But you will be. I'm giving you a chance at a life that means something. A life worth living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That said, Bethlehem delivers one last blow to The Postman's face. Everything goes BLACK...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brutal REVEILLE BLASTS the sleeping conscripts awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's move it.     Everybody up and at 'em.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Postman comes to. He licks his dry, blood-caked lips. A sudden movement startles him -- it's Woody, shoving him a battered cup of water. It's like he's been keeping watch. The Postman is surprised, a little suspicious, and very grateful as he gulps the water down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.   Did I win?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody shakes his head "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to tell him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words you said in town. About the wind blowing. And the rest... Say it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Blow, wind. Come wrack. At least we'll die with the harness off our back.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Live free or die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody and The Postman scramble to fall-to with the other conscripts. Idaho surveys the ranks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, girls. We're gonna run. Twenty miles. With packs. You got three hours. Everybody makes it. Or nobody eats.

dialogues.speaker: MEAT
dialogues.text: A COOK dumps a scoop of gristly, gray meat into each mess pail as the conscripts wait in line. They fall to ravenously, too hungry to taste how bad it is. Idaho supervises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat up!    You got meat tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line has almost passed. Just The Postman left and Bandit #20 bringing up the rear. Idaho looks at The Postman, addresses the COOK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell Shakespeare what kind of meat that is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably Bill -- and The Postman knows it. He stares in revulsion at the putrid meat ladled into his pail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A godawful animal. The sterile offspring of a horse and a donkey. Can you imagine that?! There's no room in this new world for a bastard like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bandit #20 holds out his pail.       But the cook won't f it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh uh. (loudly; for all) Any man last in line ain't hungry enough. You show up last, you don't eat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bandit #20 steps away in disbelief. Not knowing what else to do, he sits down beside The Postman, the only man with food who isn't eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll die before I'm last in line again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they're hoping for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds his pail out to Bandit #20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Serious?   This isn't bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost in despair, The Postman stares out at the skewed palette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These were supposed to be the best years of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conscripts stand at attention under the guard of Idah and two other soldiers. To their right is a dead oak tree. Behind them, three rows of folding chairs. Two figures approach. Bethlehem and Getty. Getty carries a sheathed sword. Bethlehem surveys the troops -- taking no more notice of The Postman than anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The laws of eight, gentlemen. That is the legacy handed down to us by Nathan Holn. At the mention of this name, the RECRUITS shout as one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God rest his soul!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May he burn in hell. Getty looks over at him. He heard him. The Postman swallows hard. Getty stares hard. Then he turns away. He's not going to bust him on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the laws that we live by. The eight is our symbol. Each man will bear it with pride. Bethlehem nods at Idaho who pushes up his own sleeve to reveal the branded 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only then will you be part of the clan. Sit down, gentlemen. The men move to sit in one of the three rows. Only then does it become apparent that there are 18 men and only 17 chairs. One SLOW RECRUIT is left standing. It doesn't take him long to realize that he's in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law One. You will obey orders without question. (to Slow Recruit)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you to sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There weren't enough chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't specify chairs. You could've sat down on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Slow Recruit moves to do so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You disobeyed a direct order.    You broke Law One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Idaho and another soldier step up beside the Slow Recruit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law Two.   Punishment shall be swift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hustle the Recruit to the tree. Idaho unslings a coil of rope, throws it over a tree limb. They quickly slip a loop over the Slow Recruit's ankles and haul him upside down into the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law Three: Mercy is for the weak. Four: Terror will defeat reason. Five: Your allegiance is to the clan. Six: Justice can be dictated. Law Seven. Any clansman may challenge for leadership of the clan. Does any man here wish to challenge me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no takers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On your feet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conscripts stand like jackknives snapping open. Without a word, without a look -- Bethlehem reaches out and draws a sword from a sheath that Getty holds. Bethlehem steps to the Slow Recruit -- who slowly twists around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law Eight: There is only one penalty: Death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem raises the sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, I'm begging you.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: As the sword finds its mark.     Bethlehem looks at him, addresses all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will get out of this army what you put into it. Work and you'll be fed. Fight and you'll be respected. Die and you'll be remembered. It's up to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem turns and walks away.     Getty following behin The Postman watches as they go.     Idaho steps up to him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thinking of challenging for leadership of the clan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.   I'm a follower not a leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see Colonel Getty? Always following the General? He's the only man who ever challenged. Fight lasted six seconds, but the General didn't kill him. He cut off his tongue and he cut off his balls and old Getty's been following him like a dog ever since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman looks back to see Bethlehem and Getty disappear into the gloom. Idaho grins, likes how this affects a new man. The Postman moves on.     Idaho stops Woody as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General don't see it, but I say you got some nigger in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody clenches his jaw, but wisely doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain as the army moves. Boots suck at the mud. War wagons heave out of ruts. A monster gun is mounted on an old John Deere semi, pulled by a team of ten horses. The conscripts fill the middle ranks, each bearing a heavy pack.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Marching beside Woody, The Postman stares blankly ahead. The cry to halt. The conscripts unsling their packs, catch their breath. Idaho pulls The Postman out of line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General would like a word with you, Shakespeare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem stands before a painter's easel, palette in hand. He's got a mirror set up so he can see his reflection. He's doing a self-portrait in the tradition of the great Dutch Masters -- but it's a dismal failure. He continues painting even as Idaho leads The Postman in. Idaho salutes, steps back. For a moment, The Postman doesn't quite know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the book and binoculars on the table) They're yours. A solitary man, aren't you? Binoculars. To watch life from a distance. And Shakespeare. To read about it instead of living it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem wants an answer.    The Postman clears his thro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No offense, General, but you seem to have read some Shakespeare yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he wishes to rise above mere thuggery, a military commandeer must be classically educated. Philosophy, history. Even a sense of the dramatic. (a beat) Do you know what I did before the war? Do you think I was in the army? I sold copying machines. I was a salesman. The talent to lead men and devise and execute a battle plan were locked away inside me.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He picks up Finding A Way to Win by Nathan Holn.     A 20 year-old self-help book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Nathan Holn hadn't come along, I'd still be selling copying machines. Can you imagine the wasted life? Can you imagine the magnitude of it? But war... War gives men like me a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to a dog-eared page in the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here... 'The prize is often left unclaimed. Have the courage to grasp it. For fortune always favors the bold.' (moved) It always inspires me. (beat) I have a design for the future. A master plan. I'll need able officers to carry it out. You have the intelligence. If your heart matches, you'll go far. (a beat) We'll talk more in the weeks to come. Dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman leaves.     Idaho stands at the ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Issue the binoculars to a scout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the book, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Idaho leaves. Bethlehem goes back to his painting. He considers himself in the mirror. After a long stare-down, he shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman rejoins the conscripts. Bandit #20 slides over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Troubled, The Postman doesn't answer. He heads for a corner where Woody stands alone. Relentless, Bandit #20 follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say anything about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the quiet corner; it's just the three of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Escaping. (low) You ever hear of St. Rose? It's on the coast. They say it's a paradise. They've even got electric lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bandit #20 looks scared, Woody unreadable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between the three of us, we could --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. I can't. I like it here. I like being a part of something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman can't believe what Bandit #20 just said. Bandit #20 turns, hurries away. The Postman looks to Woody who doesn't tip his hand eithe way. He moves away as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conscripts break camp. Hot work. Glistening with sweat, The Postman stops to stretch. Across the way, he sees Bandit #20 talking to Getty. Getty glances at The Postman who returns to work, watches under his eyebrows a Idaho joins the group. There's trouble brewing here. Worried, The Postman looks to Woody, who watches the exchange as well. He is, as usual, inscrutable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The river is swollen and swift from the spring thaw. Marching along the east ridge above it, the army is given the order to halt. The Postman looks ahead to where Idaho confers with Bethlehem. Something's wrong. They look to where: Two carbine-toting soldiers stand alertly at guard by a thicket across the river. A rotten wood and rope bridge spans the space between the ridges. Idaho rides to the conscripts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of you dogs has earned himself a treat. Over there. Idaho points to the thicket as he proceeds down the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those men hunted themselves a lion this morning. Must've been a zoo around here before the war. Anyhow, they shot him and he crawled into that thicket. A third man went in after him. We don't know if he's dead or alive. I need a volunteer. Someone's gotta go in and get our boy out. No volunteers, except the zealot Bandit #20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go. Idaho ignores him, stops in front of Woody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess size ain't a measure of courage, is it? Shakespeare! The fix is in.    The Postman steps out of line.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Idaho's about to hand The Postman a carbine when --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem nods to Getty. Getty takes a hunting knife from a belt-sheath and tosses it, blade first, into the ground between The Postman's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come out alive and you got yourself a lion steak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hefting the knife, The Postman stares at the west ridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winks) Maybe you'll find your St. Rose up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman looks to Bandit #20 who stares back defiantly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you waiting for, Christmas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bandit #20 can't contain his giggling, so Idaho backhands the sound out of him -- then looks back to The Postman. Grim The Postman starts forward, looks from the rotten bridge to the water and back again as he moves. All eyes on him as he starts across...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman steps lightly. Far below, the river rages. A knotty plank starts to crack underfoot. Scooting off it, he takes a last look around. Continues across to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers greet him -- unholy smiles on their ugly mugs. They point him ahead, prod him forward toward a trail of wet blood which leads deeper into the thicket. Stooping, The Postman enters. The soldiers split off and track along with him on either side of the thicket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thorns catch and tear at his clothes as The Postman pushe his way through. He freezes. Ahead, sprawled and twisted, the mauled, bloody corpse of a Holnist soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you stopping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He alive? Clearly he is not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring him out. The Postman heaves the corpse onto his back. Rising, steadying himself, he looks back over his shoulders at a GUTTURAL GROWL. He hurries forward.

dialogues.speaker: ARMY
dialogues.text: Everyone stares across the river, straining to see as The Postman emerges with the corpse on his back.

dialogues.speaker: ON BRIDGE
dialogues.text: The Postman starts across, hampered by his burden.   He pauses, at his feet, the cracked, knotty plank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (across river)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up! You still got a lion to bag! The Postman decides, deliberately steps on the PLANK. CRACK. The Postman and the corpse drop thirty feet down, disappear in the river below. The corpse surfaces first, floats in the water. Then The Postman. Farther down the river. Swimming downstream with powerful strokes. Between his efforts and the current, he's being quickly swept away from the Holnists. As Bethlehem's eyes narrow in fury.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A RIFLE BARKS a SHELL BACK after The Postman, but he disappears around a bend in the river. Bethlehem signals to two soldiers. They start running along the east ridge toward the riverbend. Two more start across the bridge to the west -- moving with military precision. Bethlehem wheels toward the conscripts, points out Woody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the water. Come back without him and you and another man will die in his place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody dives in the water. Bethlehem looks to Idaho who dives in as well. Conscripts buzz with nervous excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go!   Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (caught up) I'll get him, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes off running across the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fallen tree spans the river. As The Postman is swept beneath, he reaches up and catches hold. Pulling himself out of the water, he scrambles for the west shore. He disappears into the woods as two soldiers appear. They catch hold of the tree, look to the west banking, se footprints in the mud where The Postman pulled himself out. They start after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clothes in tatters, his lungs ready to burst, The Postman stops. He takes cover as the two soldiers run past. Breathing hard, The Postman steps out, starts across the clearing. He's halfway when Bandit #20 steps out from the trees. They look at each other for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just let me go. I don't want to be part of your army.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bandit #20 hesitates for a moment, then breaks into a grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My army.   I like the sound of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman gestures with his knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got him!   Over --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman lunges, digs into Bandit #20's gut.   He blin in surprise, then sags to the ground. The Postman takes a step back. A shadow falls over him. It's Woody. Staring down at The Postman. They can hear others approaching from the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sent me to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment, Idaho and the second soldier come into th clearing. Idaho grins, relaxes his grip on his gun when he sees the mismatch between Woody and The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, boy.   Get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's you or me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finish it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woody circles The Postman, until he's facing Idaho and th soldier. Woody takes a long look at The Postman, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No harness on my back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As The Postman realizes what he's doing, Woody flips his knife through the air and into the soldier's throat.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Woody rushes him, Idaho raises his GUN. Idaho pumps TWO ROUNDS into Woody, but the big man keeps coming. The THIRD ROUND finds his heart, puts Woody down. Dead. But not before he lands on top of Idaho. As Idaho struggles to get out from under Woody's massive frame, The Postman heads for the trees. Covered in Woody's blood, Idaho FIRES a ROUND as The Postman disappears into the woods. Idaho starts after him.

dialogues.speaker: IDAHO
dialogues.text: Tracking. He sees a dribble of fresh blood.   He touches it with his fingers and smiles. He cocks his head at MOVEMENT to his left. Smiling, hefting his pistol, Idaho moves in. More SHUFFLING.   Jus ahead. He's got him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want your St. Rose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a RUSTLE of BRUSH just before a ROAR splits the air. Idaho doesn't even have time to scream as the LION pounces down on top of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman, lungs heaving, stops his climb long enough t take stock of the Army waiting on the distant river edge. Strength ebbing, he heaves himself up and continues climbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chilling RAIN drills down, washing across an old forest road. Covered with undergrowth and dotted with saplings, nothing's been down here in years. Blue-lipped and shivering, his clothes torn and soaked, The Postman trudges along. He tries to rub some warmth back into his numbed limbs, but a coughing spell wracks his body.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He trudges forward, shoes heavy with freezing mud. He's made his escape, but he won't last the night if he doesn' find some shelter. An unnatural shape ahead, just off the road.    Square. cautiously pulls back a few branches. An old, rusted Jeep with faded    U.S. government marking Its hood buried under the dirt    of an old mud slide. Th Postman stoops to look through    the passenger side wind comes face-to-face with death.     A skeleton sits inside the skull grinning against the    glass facing The Postma But The Postman doesn't jump back. He just stares. The two heads meet halfway as The Postman's face is reflected on the glass, superimposed over the skull. A hypothermic shiver wracks his body. The Postman tries the door, but it won't budge. The other side of the Jeep is buried. But seeing that the windshield is partly smashed, he clears away the debris, peels back the spider webbed safety glass and climbs inside.

dialogues.speaker: JEEP
dialogues.text: Pulling the glass back down, he looks almost shyly at the skeleton, like two kids about to "park" for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.   How ya doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The back of the Jeep is filled with bags marked U.S. Mail The Postman picks up a hat off the console. Oddly respectful, he runs a finger along the band over the "Horse & Rider" emblem. The Postman reaches, touches the embroidered American fla patch on the skeleton's jacket shoulder. Another shiver. A moment later, The Postman is pulling the nice dry jacke off the skeleton and shoving his own arms inside. A sloshing sound. He pats down the jacket. Finds a liquor. He gives the skeleton a "you shouldn't have" look. But the cap won't budge. He twists, pries, bangs the neck of the steering wheel. At last it gives. He takes a long, hard swallow. The warming fire streams down his throat. The Postman grabs a random letter, reads it aloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Jerry Ball, Pine View.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to open it, looks at the skeleton and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, arrest me. (reading) Here's a piece of good news. Jerry's decided to go to school to get his contractor's license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tossing it aside, he takes a drink, opens another.   The words are in crayon -- a child's scrawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles to skeleton) Little Jimmy wants his grandpa to know he lost a tooth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman turns the envelope over in his palm. A tiny tooth falls out. The Postman considers it. This suddenly isn't so amusing. He puts it back in the envelope. Shoving mail sacks aside, he climbs in the back. Burrowing in, he pulls the sacks back, covering himself with a blanket of mail. Getting warmer already, he regards the skeleton a beat as the RAIN DRUMS ON the ROOF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing the blue uniform, The Postman looks down at the fresh grave, realizes a eulogy is in order. He takes off the hat, holds it over his chest for a heartfelt moment o silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for being there for me. (raising the flask) Here's to you. I consider my taxes very well spent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swallows the last few drops, then sets the flask down as a headstone. What now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All dressed up. Nowhere to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hair growing back nicely, The Postman has reached the proverbial fork in the road. He considers his two options: "Pine View -- 32 miles." Or "Ridgemont -- 220 miles." He looks the two roads over, thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town is protected by a tall, long palisade.     Like Apache. All is dark as The Postman approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greetings, Pine View, Oregon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO SENTRIES appears from the gate house.    They aim arrows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just head back the way you came. Pine View ain't buying, ain't listening and don't give charity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment of truth is here.    Finally, with authority:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Civilian, I'm on official business. I demand entry into the town of Pine View.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm through talking to you, buddy boy! Now get somebody with authority to open this gate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More silhouettes appear on the palisade.     One is SHERI BRISCOE, a big, no-nonsense man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Sheriff Briscoe. Who the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a representative of the United States Government --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An uproar.    He makes himself heard above it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Authorized by order 417 of the restored Congress to reestablish a communication route to Idaho and lower Oregon. Now open that damn gate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean in English?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your postman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a silent hush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to someone on wall) Hand me your gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Understand that tampering with or obstructing the mail is a federal offense. Furthermore, the Bolin Act requires you to provide all mail carriers with sanctuary and nourishment. (starting forward) Now open that damn gate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got three seconds to get your ass outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Jerry the contractor here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briscoe pumps his shotgun, aims it at The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! I'm going to get something out of my bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman dumps the pack over, frantically shuffles through the letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Davis!   124 Vernon Street!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of him. Two!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lois Kent!   14 Weymoth Lane!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fumbles for the last letter.       Briscoe takes aim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irene March!   478 River Road!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an absolute stunned silence.      Like a switch w thrown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd parts as everyone turns to look back at IRENE MARCH. Mrs. March, in her late 50s, is blind, her eyes clouded by cataracts. In disbelief...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sense of hope is palpable as the gates are swung back Two TOWNIES hurry Mrs. March out to meet The Postman. They're followed by a throng. As he sees she's blind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too late now. They stop Mrs. March in front of him. stares off just to his left, a little afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Irene March.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) I have a letter for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses it into her hands, but she won't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you read it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it's personal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.   Someone has to.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Postman has little choice.     As he opens the envelope...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're delivering the old stock piles, but I'll accept all new correspondence as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just read it, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excited, the people move closer.      Someone holds up a and The Postman starts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Dear Irene. Sorry I haven't written. Everything's so crazy. The strange weather. The food shortages. That farmer Nathan Holn causing all that trouble. It's hard to understand. David's home from the Army. The war was over before he even got there. Thank God for that. He's still my baby no matter how big he gets. We're going to miss you for Christmas, but maybe next year. All our love. Donna.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. March reaches out a trembling hand to take the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sister in Denver. Fifteen years ago. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The populace erupts with excitement.        Mrs. March ta Postman's hand, clasps it tightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a Godsend. A savior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman pulls his hand back, rejects the title.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.   I'm just... a postman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An almost awesome silence.     Too much for The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been on the road a while. I could use a little something to eat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, absolutely... Is there anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The townspeople welcome him with cheers. The Postman raises a silencing hand. As they quiet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, there is! If there are dogs in this town, you have to leash them while I'm here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only The Postman laughs. No one else reacts. Briscoe watches dubiously from the wall as the people surround Th Postman and sweep him through the gates and into town. One couple watches The Postman closely as he makes his wa into town. She is ABBY -- a sweet-faced, pretty woman. Her husband, MICHAEL, is a decent-looking sort, tall and strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A freestanding tub has been set up, water "bucketed" in. The Postman luxuriates in his first hot bath in years and sings a familiar tune to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Stop. Oh, yes, wait a minute, Mr. Postman. Waaa-ait, Mr. Postman...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FORD crosses the parking lot of an abandoned motel. He's a black kid, maybe 16, too young to remember any other life but this. He carries The Postman's uniform on a hanger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman looks up at a KNOCK. Ford steps in. Like most kids, he needs a hero. Holding up the uniform, he just found one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming) Cleaned and pressed, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Didn't somebody say something about dinner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm supposed to take you to Foster's. (extending a hand) My name's Ford. Ford Lincoln Mercury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman just nods, hoisting himself out of the tub an hurriedly wrapping a towel around himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to be John Stevens, but I changed it on account of I want to drive cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoping to impress, Ford reaches into a pocket, pulls out worn, creased flyer for a "Ford Lincoln Mercury" dealership. Ford finds The Postman just staring at him, waiting for the uniform he's still got in his hand. Embarrassed, Ford quickly hands it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford leads the way as they leave the motel behind. The Postman looks good in his uniform. They cross a parking lot where five partly-stripped cars have been sitting for years. There's a potted plant outside the driver's door of one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I live in that car. A 2003 Pontiac Sinatra. With a nine- banger and a Q-eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: V-eight. Eight cylinders.   That means an eight-banger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in awe of him) Were they fast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A buck seventy-five on a strip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A buck seventy-five? I thought maybe I could fix some of them up. It's nothing compared to what you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the last thing he expected to hear out of this kid's mouth. A moment, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The important thing to remember about cars is, you can't eat 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahead, people are gathered inside an old Foster's Freeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The townspeople fill the booths, line the walls. They talk excitedly amongst themselves, break into spontaneous applause as Ford and The Postman enter. The Postman is surprised, uncomfortable at this display. But then he sees that a banquet has been laid out on the counter. The centerpiece is a huge vat of steaming stew. The PEOPLE clear a path for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us about the government!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, tell us everything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Startled, The Postman doesn't quite know what to say. They seat him at a table -- but the food looks miles away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a President?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I'm pretty hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But these people won't be denied.       Finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is, uh... Richard Starkey. From Maine. He has a saying. 'Things are getting better, getting better all the time.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's warm applause at that.    Several people try the expression out on each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He a Democrat or a Republican?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parties are over with. The individual is what counts. You vote for the best man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ellen sets a steaming bowl of stew in front of The Postman. Famished, he digs in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Europe? Any word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman tries to speak through a mouthful of food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady Di's in charge. Sixty years old and she still kicks ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Nathan Holn still alive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles at irony) He died. Skin cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's sure good news to everyone.       But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the Holnists? They're still out there. What's the government going to do about them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman looks at the desperate faces -- he'd rather get back to his meal -- but this may be the most importan question of all. He doesn't want to lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The government's just getting started. You're on your own for at least eighteen months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the Marines Corp?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clamor of Holnist questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quiet, everyone! Can't we just let this man eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people nod and The Postman finally gets to eat. He catches sight of Briscoe watching him from the door. After a moment, Briscoe leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A band plays an odd array of instruments. There's dancing. The Postman sits behind four empty bowls. People watch him eat like it was a religious experience. He pushes back the fifth bowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never thought I'd hear myself say this, but I can't eat anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's cut off by the sight of a silent, little boy.    The kid's looking up, staring intently at something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy just stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re:   the cap) This?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy nods. The Postman shakes his head and smiles to himself. He takes off the cap, sets it on the kid's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost fits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy's eyes go wide with wonder. His stock's gone up 1000%. Before he can rush off to impress his friends, ELLEN -- his mother -- steps over and gently chides him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a toy, honey. That's very important. Give it back.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The boy carefully removes the cap, hands it back to The Postman. Ellen smiles gratefully and gently guides her son away. The Postman shrugs, turns to find Abby, the pretty woman we saw at the Pine View gates. She smiles at The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I can, I think I'm still on duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs.    Abby says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby holds out her hand like a promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you got to do is hold on.

dialogues.speaker: DANCE FLOOR
dialogues.text: Abby and The Postman dance.          She keeps looking hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How tall are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About six feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you smart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smarter than some I guess.       Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just wondering. Did you ever have the bad mumps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman smiles.    She's odd, but beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never had the bad mumps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever had herpes or syphilis or anything like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head "no."    They continue to dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So as far as you know, you have good semen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a trick question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean to be nosy. I'm only asking because I want you to make me pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunned, The Postman stops dancing.      Abby takes this moment to grab Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) It's got to be the uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby takes Michael's arm, introduces him proudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my husband.    Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael smiles, shakes hands with a grave-digger's grip. The Postman doesn't know what to think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been trying to have a baby for three years. We can't on account of Michael had the bad mumps when he was twelve. So we need a body father. We could ask a man here, but it could cause trouble. I've seen it happen. Things go okay until the woman starts to show. Then it can be bad. But you'll only be around once in awhile with the mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman just stares at them.      Abby looks to Micha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't said 'no'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (undaunted) What do you say, mister?     You'd be doing us a favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman excuses himself with a nod and turns away, shaking his head at the strangeness of this new world. But no rest for the wicked, as soon as he's free from Abb and Michael, he's running smack into another group of well-wishing TOWNIES. Mrs. March is among them. She's holding an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. March wants to give you something. (to Mrs. March) He's right here, Irene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: letter) It's to my daughter Annie. She left five years ago. She was only fifteen. The last I heard, she was living up north...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman swallows hard, looks from the envelope to the faces around him, to Mrs. March. She looks blindly back. How can he lie to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mrs. March, you should know that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she stops him, grabs for his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a feeling about you. I know you'll do what's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hand leaves his and she disappears into the crowd. She's left him with her letter and no choice at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman moves through town. The streets are deserted. He's got his pack on, his mailbag. He passes a 7-11 converted to a blacksmith shop. There's a horse tethered to the railing in front of it. He grins; maybe he's going to make it out of here after all. As he starts to move toward the horse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's right around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OLD MAN sits on his porch across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (freezes, startled) What is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you're looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man winks knowingly, then heads inside. As The Postman turns the corner, he finds himself in front of th post office. An old brick building. Chiseled in the granite facing: "UNITED STATES POST OFFICE. EST. 1884."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long ago stripped, it still has a proud, official, almost holy feel. The Postman wanders in, stops to read the credo calligraphied on the wall. "Neither snow, nor rain..." He turns at a SOUND. Ford is here, leaning against a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'd come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford nods.    A sage sixteen-year-old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you get to be a postman, anyhow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to be in the right place at the right time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you wanted to drive cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not anymore. That was kid's stuff. This is real. So, where's the right place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be anywhere. Anytime. Only another postman can make you a postman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinda like vampires, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that. You have to be sworn in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford raises his right hand, palm out, ready to take the oath. It takes The Postman a moment to realize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The organization's kinda shaky. It might not last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd meet a lot of people who don't believe in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll set them straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lonely job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been lonely all my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This response strikes a chord. The Postman sees how badly Ford wants something to hold onto. He sees himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So have I, Ford. So have I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman looks up at the creed on the wall.    Finally

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell?     Repeat after me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating) Neither snow, nor rain, nor heat nor gloom of night stays these couriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating) Okay, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no, I'm saying that. You just listen... By my authority you are now empowered to carry the mail. (extends a hand) Congratulations, you're a postman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands. The Postman doesn't realize, but this is the most important moment in Ford's life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to know I'd die to get a letter through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford's intensity takes The Postman back.       But the mo is broken when...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny, why don't you run along. I need to speak to this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford bristles at "Johnny," looks to The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure thing, Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny's real impressed with you. Whole town's real impressed with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take it you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smarter than you look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, Sheriff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can clear out. Or I can throw you out. Either way suits me fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you don't understand, Sheriff. I'm a government employee. Authorized by --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not authorized by shit. You're nothing but a drifter who found a bag of mail. And I want you out of my town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is going in my report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people don't need dreams, Mr. Postman. They need something real. They need help with the goddamn Holnists. Are you going to bring them that? (as The Postman doesn't answer) Didn't think so. All you cost us so far is a few bowls of soup and maybe later a few broken hearts. I aim to keep it that way. You can stay till morning. Then I don't ever want to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briscoe exits, leaves The Postman alone in the post office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
