dialogues.text: What Ford did was wrong. But it doesn't change anything for any of us. Does it?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks to the other carriers -- it's written all over their faces -- they stand with Ponytail and Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem looks the line-up over. The firing squad stands at the ready. Bethlehem looks to the trees -- feeling something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Getty) He's out there somewhere. Watching. I can feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briscoe follows his gaze. He doesn't see anything, but maybe gets the same feeling. Bethlehem looks to Briscoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel it too, don't you? Didn't have to end like this, Sheriff. He knew where I'd be if he wanted to face me like a man. Instead, he's hiding like a rabbit. So much for your Postman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready!    Aim!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rifles are raised. Briscoe seems to grow as he throws his shoulders back and shouts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ride, Postman! Ride! You hear me? I said ride!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WORDS ECHO.       Nothing The Postman can do, but wat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem's eyes go wild --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RIFLES BARK.      Everyone falls dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something in The Postman breaks. He just lies there. witnesses move back, taking The Postman with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Briscoe lies dead.   The letter from his sister blows from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman folds a letter, shoves it into an envelope. He writes "Bethlehem" across the front, starts to write a second letter. The door opens and Abby enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford thinks you're going to do something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. The Postman watches as, outside, the mail carriers begin to assemble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I don't, those kids are going to keep on getting themselves killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford doesn't know what it means to be a kid. He doesn't have your memories. None of them do. All they've got is the lousy world we gave them. And this is the only decent thing in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Being a postman? It's all bullshit, Abby. All of it. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took this uniform off a skeleton to stay warm. I made up the rest to stay fed. There is no restored United States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it was something like that. The Postman fingers the brim of the cap, softens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weird thing is, being a Postman was almost the best thing that ever happened to me... (re: red ribbon) Remember this? You left it behind that night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always liked to think you left it on purpose. But maybe you just forgot it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby doesn't answer.    She leaves instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve mail carriers, including Ford, Ponytail, Chubby, Luke and Old George, wait as The Postman steps up before them. Abby's off to the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this everybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest are on the overdue list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is everybody. (for all) Got a letter from President Starkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An excited murmur among the carriers. Only Ford eyes The Postman suspiciously. The Postman reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Greetings all carriers.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greetings, President Starkey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) 'I've been in contact with The Postman. I've received all the reports. I'm proud of you all.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at them, doesn't need to read what's in his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In dark days, in a weary world, you gave everything and asked for nothing. You beat back despair and replaced it with hope and for that your country can never repay you. But the price is too high. I won't see anymore of my bravest die. It is my duty to hereby disband the Postal Service of the restored United States. You are to burn your uniforms and The Postman is to return to Minneapolis at once. Thank you and that is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hushed silence. The Postman walks away. The carriers exchange tired, defeated looks. Abby just sighs, knows he's not necessarily wrong. Ford catches up with The Postman.    He stares at The Postman; The Postman stares back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low; fierce) The President never wrote that letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he could've that's what he would have said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford gestures to the second letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the other letter to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem. I'm taking it to him in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mail's private. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops; turns) It says it's over. It says we quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says you quit. What about the oath?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something, Ford. How much mail can a dead postman deliver? It's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman starts to walk away again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't trust you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford gathers courage and confronts The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this is the end. If this is the last piece of mail that ever gets delivered. I'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever takes this letter probably dies for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford thrusts out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm still a postman. You owe it to me... I owe it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman hesitates, studies the intense young man. Gives him the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman is packing bags onto a horse as Abby approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to St. Rose, Abby. And I'm taking you with me. I know you don't want to hear it, but that's my child inside you. I want to see it born somewhere safe. I have a right to that, Abby. Whether you like it or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby walks away. The Postman rests his head on his pack for a moment. Heavy.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The CLICK of a GUN causes The Postman to lift his head an see Luke standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought I recognized you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Bethlehem said... (raises the pistol) ... You should be on your knees when I do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn what that asshole said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The general is a great man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The general is a fucking lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman steps forward. Stops when the barrel of the pistol is right against his own chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't own a thought in that goddamn head of yours, do you? (a beat) You want to see a man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman turns to watch as Ford starts out of camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman turns, sees Luke's face fraught with confusio and emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand, do you? You never will until you can think for yourself and be willing to pay the price for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke stares back into The Postman's eyes.      A frozen b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Abby sits on her horse. She's witness to it all. Luke is confused and ashamed. The Postman mounts his horse and moves to Abby's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a better man than Bethlehem, Luke. I've seen it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some carriers drop their uniforms into a bonfire. The Postman and Abby ride up on the ridge above the RV camp. They pause to look back one last time. Across the way, on the other side, Ford is doing the same thing. As though he senses it, Ford stops and looks back. Ford raises his hand, salutes. Slowly, The Postman brings up his own hand. But he doesn't salute. He waves. Good- bye. As Ford turns away, so does The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: ON CHUBBY, PONYTAIL AND CARRIER NAMED DREW
dialogues.text: watching as The Postman and Abby disappear from sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess Minneapolis is that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign prohibits pedestrians, horses and bicycles. The Postman and Abby ride by. The Postman no longer wears his uniform. Their gear is packed behind their saddles. As a family of transients begin to rise from where they'r camped in the breakdown lane:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't help you. We're just as lost as you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman rides on. Abby watches over her shoulder as they slowly begin to sit back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem sits waiting at his camp table.     Behind him, finished painting.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: This time he's painted himself in the grand Rococo-style - as part of the Holy Family with doves and flowers and glowing rays from Heaven. It's awful. Getty and Gibbs bring in a prisoner.       It's Ford!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good lord, what do we have here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a representative of the restored United States --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem backhands Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a letter. Says The Postman sent it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem tears open the letter and starts to read:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bethlehem. This letter is my testimony to the fact that there is no restored United States and there is no Postal Service.' (laugh; grim) Then who the hell have we been fighting...? (reads on) 'My carriers are returning home. In exchange, I'm asking you to let them be. The Postman.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem eyes Ford with undisguised contempt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He expects me to believe this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true, sir. I was there. He disbanded the carriers and rode west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford turns blazing eyes to Luke -- he's been standing there all along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Traitor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes a moment for the news to sink in.      But it do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I've won.     I've won.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the assembled Holnists congratulate each other, Bethlehem looks at Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were supposed to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't get close enough. (re: Ford) This one's his second in command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem looks Ford over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why doesn't that surprise me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford stares back.    Proud.     Bethlehem looks to Getty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring out the one we found yesterday. They can die together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A frightened CARRIER is brought up. He wears a purple uniform with CALI sewn on the shoulder. Neither we nor Ford have seen him before. As a firing squad assembles, Ford is shoved over with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name's Clark. Postal Carrier of the restored Republic of California. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford looks at him a second, can't help but laugh.      Fr Gibbs; the shout of "ready!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Postmaster Ford Lincoln Mercury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem watches as Clark holds out his hand.      Ford shakes it. "Aim!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... wait a minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold your fire! You don't know each other? (to himself, quiet anger building) This will never be over. It'll go on except I'll be fighting a goddamn ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we fire, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No goddamnit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem crumples the letter, tosses it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I won't fight a ghost. Tabula rasa, gentlemen. A clean slate. I want all mail carriers hunted down. I want The Postman found. I want him dealt with. (to Getty) Colonel, organize the scouts. (to Luke) He rode west?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of boots are walking through the water. It's The Postman. He turns over a body in the water. It wears a homemade postal uniform, a bag of mail twisted around his arm. It's a young face, one we haven't seen before. He looks up to Abby on a ridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know him. Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Where do you think he came from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puzzled, The Postman shakes his head. He gently releases the body. The current takes it and they watch as it continues on its way to Postal Valhalla.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family of transients are grilled by three Holnist scouts. One man points the way Abby and Bethlehem rode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Littered with rubble. The wood, brick, steel and concrete of what was once a small town. Amazingly, one gray house still stands, miraculously untouched by whatever disaster visited this place. A wild-haired SQUATTER steps out on the porch as Abby and The Postman ride by. He waves hello with a .45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy. Welcome to sunny California.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the town)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little accident. The ground started to shake big time and the Hanford nuclear plant went... (motions an explosion)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... 'Poof.' Destroyed everything for miles. But the sunsets are beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever hear of a city called St. Rose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friend, I've never heard of St. Shit. The Squatter laughs and laughs -- like it was the funnies thing in the world. The Postman and Abby exchange a look, continue on their way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, don't go! I got Monopoly in the house! Boardwalk, Park Place and the Reading Railroad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ponytail, Chubby, and Draw watching from afar.    Chubby the telescope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that's President Starkey?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ponytail takes the telescope from Chubby for a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you so sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President lives in a white house. That guy's place is gray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drew and Chubby exchange a look.       That makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lightning bolt shreds the sky.       It's day, but the black with rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The useless towers cutting across a valley.      Rain bea down, as The Postman and Abby trudge along. Up ahead, a rail-road tunnel promises shelter from the storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the tunnel) We can rest in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby is quick to agree. Out of the corner of his eye, The Postman catches a blur of movement. He turns his head quickly, but he's barely in time to see a wooden basket, attached to one of the high wires, swing from a distant tower. There's a sentry inside it. The basketed sentry whistles away at 40 mph, heading straight for an adjacent tower. In a matter of seconds, he's lost from view. The Postman looks back at Abby.       She's shivering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) I'm hungry, Postman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman guides her toward the train tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby sleeps beside the fire. The Postman, silhouetted against the flames, heads toward the far tunnel exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman peers into the rain, taking in the view of a distant bridge. Abby comes to stand at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A town settled between spans of a steel truss bridge. The Columbia River rushes far below. A sentry spots Abby and The Postman approaching, blows a whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set the rifle on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This old thing? It isn't even loaded. Where are we? The BRIDGE CITY MAYOR, a middle-aged retro-hippie, steps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in Bridge City. Where we don't allow guns. The Postman sets down the carbine.    The Guard steps ove to scoop it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sentry said you were coming. The Postman stares at the Mayor a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you.     You're famous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was once. Not anymore. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you looking to cross?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will be. Right now, we'd just appreciate some food. (as the Mayor nods his assent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got some kids behind me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three. (as the Mayor agrees once more) Hey, guys, come on in! I know you're out there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, is he smart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they stand, show themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fog rolls in.    Abby rests. Ponytail, Chubby and Drew look up gratefully as one of th citizens of Bridge City doles out bread. The Mayor steps over, hands The Postman two loaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For you and your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.    She's not my wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exchange cuts Abby like a knife. She gets up and leaves. The Mayor keeps his council -- not sure what to make of this arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something, have you ever heard of a town with electric lights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: St. Rose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never been. But they say it's a ways down on the coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple hundred miles at least.   I couldn't say for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the discovery of a lifetime. The Postman looks to the west end of the bridge, where Abby stands alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem like a decent man. And these seem like decent people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We try to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this seems like a safe place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (intuitive) You want to leave her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman looks back to the Mayor, then slowly nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them. I'll give you the horses and my gear. Abby's special. She's strong. Probably end up running the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you take the night to think. Decide if that's what you really want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fog obscures the east end. A sentry squints at the MUFFLED CLOP of HOOVES. The mist parts to reveal, seventy yards away: three Holnist scouts on horseback. Emissaries from hell. As the sentry blows a whistle...

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGE
dialogues.text: As word spreads, folks move down the bridge for a look. Eating their bread, The Postman, Abby and the carriers join them.

dialogues.speaker: EAST END
dialogues.text: The Mayor stands across from the lead scout -- conferring Finally, the Mayor points him back the way he came. The lead scout doesn't budge, spots The Postman in the crowd. He and The Postman seem to stare at each other forever. Then, with a flick of the reins, he's gone. The other two follow. Swallowed up by the misty evening gloom. The Postman's head swims dizzily. It's not over. The Mayor returns to dozens of nervous questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're looking for The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No such thing anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man on the horse says there is. Says he thinks he's here. Says he's coming back with friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little BOY steps forward, sings out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a postman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silent moment. It's been so long, no one's sure how to answer. The Postman looks down at the ground. The carriers exchange deflated looks. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping forward) You never heard of a postman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes his head "no." Seems a shame. As The Postman looks over at Abby, she takes a page from his book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There used to be a postman for every street in America. They wore uniforms. And hats. Like this one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to The Postman's gear, returns with his postal cap. Sets it on the boy's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My postman knew the name of every kid on my street. He knew our birthdays. He'd even find the baseballs you'd hit down the street. I can still see the smile on his face. The tip of his cap -- when he had a letter in his bag with my name on it. Mine always came just after school. You could set your watch by him. Unless you were waiting on something special -- like a present from somewhere far away or a letter from your sweetheart. Then it seemed like he'd never come. I used to think they could make time stand still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several other listeners nod -- they're completely with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we ever really understood what they meant to us until they were gone. Getting a letter made you feel like you were part of something bigger than yourself. No place was ever too far away for the postman. So nobody ever had to be alone. The postman was someone you could count on. Things just made more sense when they were around. (beat) That's the kind of world we used to have. A world a lot of us took for granted. And now we've got this one. And it makes me wonder -- what kind of world do I want my child to live in? I want my child to live in a world where hopes and dreams aren't just lies you tell yourself to get through another day. I want my child, and I want my friends -- I want all of us to live in a world where you still get your mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a   moment before anyone speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to The Postman) Are you The Postman?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Postman takes the cap off the little boy's head, touches the emblem, and answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard of you, man. You're famous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess I am. And all of a sudden, I'm not wearing the right clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as he puts on his cap, he accepts the mantle as well.

dialogues.speaker: PINE BOX
dialogues.text: lowered from the top of the bridge. Hands reach up to steady it and bring it gently to the ground. It's one of many. The Postman and Abby gasp as the Mayor opens the lid to reveal: 20 well-oiled rifles and 15 pistols with ammo. The Postman blinks over at the Mayor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fact that we don't allow 'em doesn't mean we don't have 'em. We're not stupid, after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I've brought this on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need to be sorry. Long as we get our mail on time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready for duty, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman looks over to see Ponytail, Drew and Chubby ride up. Like him, they are back in uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The order was to burn all uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriers look away -- sheepish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what to do then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to the people. Gather who's willing. Tell them it's important. Tell them we can make a difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And tell 'em we're going to kick ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, tell them that, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the edge of the Gorge. The three carriers, and the mounted locals thunder off the bridge and down the road. High above...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor is in the b.g. helping one of the sentries prepare the basket for travel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is hard for me. (beat) Michael was the best man I ever knew. I never thought there'd be another man I could love the way I loved him. (searching for the words) I don't know why I've been so blessed. And I've tried to find a way to be thankful, but I swear, if I lose you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her eyes start to tear and he takes her in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby, do you think a lie can become the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but I believe in you. You have a gift, Postman.     I saw it back in Pine View.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made Mrs. March feel like she could see again. You made Ford feel like he was part of the world. You give out hope like it was candy in your pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to speak.    She stops him, taking his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you come back, we'll be waiting here for you. So you can take us to St. Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman lets go of her hand and starts for the basket The Mayor gestures to the line of towers extending into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's three good-sized towns up that way. Enough folks to be a big help to you. If you can convince them to come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As The Postman steps into the basket, he makes the mistak of looking over the edge. It's a long, long way down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot higher than it looks, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman looks at the contraption with more than a little trepidation. The Mayor grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell anybody, but I like to ride the damn thing just for the hell of it. Being a city official has its perks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He winks and as he reaches for the release pin.     The Postman's hand meets his there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, man. This'll get you there a lot faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I stop --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's too late.    The Mayor releases the pin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. Good luck and Godspeed.

dialogues.speaker: COUNTERWEIGHT
dialogues.text: Plummeting into the Columbia River Gorge.      The Mayor out a rebel yell.

dialogues.speaker: BASKET
dialogues.text: The Postman is whipped along, past the riders below. speed exhilarating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town's gone, but the palisade remains. Chubby rides along it, exhorting the people who watch from above. But it's The Postman we hear, all the magic back in his voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once more into the breach, dear friends, once more. Or close the wall with our dead. In peace nothing so becomes a man as modesty and humility. But when the blast of war blows in our ears, then imitate the action of the tiger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few makeshift structures are back up. Carrying a torch, Ponytail gallops hard into town. People wake, including Mrs. March's daughter. As Ponytail speaks to them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Summon up the blood. Disguise fair nature with rage and lend the eye a terrible aspect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captured by a Holnist cavalry patrol, Old George and four other carriers are lined up, hands bound before them. Holnist soldiers force them to their knees as Gibbs organizes an impromptu firing squad.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Old George looks down the line.    The carriers are about break down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady, boys, steady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as Gibbs steps up, all hope is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In accordance with Law Eight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get on with it, you floppy-eared sonuvabitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the faces of the young carriers. Defeated, bitter. But there's a sudden spark in Old George's eyes. He starts to rise. The soldiers pick up their guns and that's when they see The Postman.

dialogues.speaker: THE POSTMAN
dialogues.text: Riding over the crest. Galloping toward them. Behind him, forty new mail carriers. All riding like mad. One of them carries the flag of the restored United States. Gibbs and his men run for their horses. SHOTS are FIRED. Four Holnists go down. The rest gallop away. The Postman and his carriers meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Converging. The Postman with his forty-five coming from the west. Drew, Chubby, and a ragtag thirty coming from the north. And from the south, Ponytail leading a contingent of fifty! The forces converge and continue east.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The army has gathered.    Three hundred strong. Bethlehem and Getty stand outside the command tent, listening to a winded, frightened Gibbs. We FOLLOW Bethlehem's eyes OVER Gibbs' SHOULDERS TO the horizon, where he sees: The Postman and his army of two hundred carriers cresting a distant rise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We were outnumbered, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A least a hundred. With guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feigning shock) With guns? Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks more like two hundred to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps away to get a better vantage point of the approaching army. He reaches out -- Getty hands him a pair of binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (donning a pair of leather gloves) Only thing worse than a coward is one who can't count. Lieutenant, do yourself a favor. Die well in this battle. In my army a deserter's life is a brief and unpleasant one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem watches The Postman through the binoculars -- a hint of a smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) At last, someone with courage enough to bring the fight to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Holnist soldier stands by with Bethlehem's horse.   The General mounts -- the model of military calm and precision. Getty reins up beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reckoning, gentlemen. This is the day I've dreamed of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sea of wildflowers separates the carriers from the Holnists. The monster John Deere gun is ready for battle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem stands with Getty, scanning the postal line wit his binoculars. The carriers look, just spoiling for a fight. Bethlehem lowers his binoculars, smiles grimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're an eager-looking bunch. Morale's a dangerous thing. (to Getty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring him up. I want this postman to see how the game is played.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman, Chubby, Ponytail and Old George and all the carriers have taken positions. The Postman sights through a telescope. He scans further down the line -- then stops when he sees Ford. Bloody, beaten within inches of his life. He's shackled -- surrounded by Holnist guards. The Postman's eyes turn to stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to carriers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here. No one moves until I give the orders. He clicks his horse forward, toward the Holnist line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem, flanked by Getty and the Holnist Sergeant, watches as The Postman makes his approach. He reaches into his pocket, withdraws a white kerchief and holds it in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they surrendering?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I hope not. He watches for a moment as The Postman crosses the field - moving well within range of Holnist fire. Then, he coaxes his horse forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem and The Postman riding toward each other. They meet when The Postman is almost three-quarters of the way over to the Holnists' side.

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM AND POSTMAN
dialogues.text: As they come face-to-face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My little shipping clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're both a couple of frauds. You know it; I know it. Bethlehem sneers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great men are made by other great men. Patton had Rommel. Grant had Lee. But I get you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're no fucking   general. You're a copying machine   salesman. You're not even a   good painter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to goad me into a fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be great if wars could be fought just by the assholes who started them? We could settle this thing right here. You and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, it doesn't work that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does in your army. The Postman kicks his horse up into a gallop, and rides u the Holnist line. No one, least of all Bethlehem, is sure what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I invoke law seven of the Laws of Eight! Any man may challenge for leadership of the clan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman wheels his horse around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I challenge you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem is caught completely by surprise, but recovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not a Holnist. You're not a member of the clan. You don't have the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman rolls up his sleeve. He rides the Holnist lines displaying his brand for all to see. The Holnists murmur amongst themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have every right. I invoke law seven!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem can't believe his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I challenge for leadership of the clan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seed of doubt is planted. Is Bethlehem violating one of the Laws of Eight? The men look at one another. Gibbs looks to Getty. Bethlehem looks from The Postman's tattoo to his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do I know you from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cry Havoc! And let slip the dogs of war.' Remember that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shakespeare. The one who didn't want to fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should've found a way to kill you then. But you seemed so strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law seven it is. (to all) This war is settled here!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As The Postman nods in agreement. They take their positions -- and without a word -- they kick their horses into a charge. Coming straight for each other like medieval jousters. Bethlehem reaches for his sword.    But before it clears scabbard, The Postman lunges. The horses collide.    Bethlehem and The Postman hit the ground hard. Holnists and Carriers alike begin to move forward for a better look. The fight is fierce. Bloody. The Postman and Bethlehem are at each other like coiled snakes. It's more of a fight than any of the Holnists -- especially Getty -- expected. The spectators pull in tighter. Both combatants have taken a beating -- and still, they fight on -- trading bloody, raw-knuckled punches. One of Bethlehem's connects. The Postman loses his footing, hits the ground -- knocking his head on a rock with a resounding CRACK. Dazed, he's slow to rise. It's just the moment Bethlehem needs, he straddles the fallen Postman, reaches for his knife with one hand -- grabs The Postman's throat with the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I study people. I know your problem. Do you know why you can't fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman can't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have nothing to fight for. You don't care about anything. You don't value anything. You don't believe in anything. That's what makes me better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman grabs Bethlehem's knife-hand -- using all his remaining strength to keep him at bay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible) I believe in the United States Postal Service.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Postman lets go of Bethlehem's hands, grabs his belt and pulls him over. As they roll to their feet, The Postman club-fists Bethlehem on the side of the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither snow... (wham!) Nor rain... (wham!) Nor heat... (wham!) Nor gloom of night... (wham!) Will stay this courier from the swift completion of his appointed rounds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem reels, stumbling back. The Postman pounces on top of him, begins to strangle him. Bethlehem tries to pry the fingers from his throat, but can't. He's going to die. The Postman is urged on. By both sides. Holnists. Carriers. Ford. Even Holnist Luke. He looks up at the faces -- and finally lets Bethlehem go. The General gasps for breath. As Ponytail and Chubby move forward to untie Ford, The Postman looks to both sides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't have to be this way. We don't have to kill each other. We can live together. We can --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford takes Chubby's pistol, sets it against the side of Bethlehem's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law three.   Mercy is for the weak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford, don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bethlehem shakes his head -- doesn't want him to, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law eight. There is only one penalty and that penalty is death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford's going to shoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He isn't worth it. I'm the head of the clan now! There are going to be new laws! (to all) Law one! No more killing! There's going to be peace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman looks at carriers and Holnists alike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else?   Who else has a law?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone has to learn how to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's law two. Who else?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three.    Liberty and justice for all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four.    No more tattoos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law five.   Give peace a chance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law six. Mercy is, it's okay sometimes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven!    Bring back vacations!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman nods solemnly, looks to Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about it, Ford Lincoln Mercury? You give us law eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford grits his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (close -- for Ford) Be a leader, Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Law eight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford FIRES! Bethlehem flinches, then sags as he realizes Ford has fired into the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Live and let live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman smiles in relief as Ford lowers the revolver and starts to hand the weapon over. Forgotten for an instant, Bethlehem makes a last, wild lunge, grabs Ford's gun. As Bethlehem aims at The Postman, a SHOT rings out. Hit in the chest, Bethlehem blinks in amazement before he falls to the ground, dying. Getty has shot him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would I had bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing and bear-baiting. Oh, had I but followed the arts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grow like savages -- as soldiers will -- that nothing do but mediate on blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getty throws his rifle on the ground. Other weapons are laid down. The war, at long last, is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody take a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter...

dialogues.speaker: INT. ABBY'S PLACE, (BRIDGE CITY)
dialogues.text: Abby, in bed, holding her new baby in her arms. She's reading a letter. What she reads makes her smile. She puts the letter down and cuddles her baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your daddy wrote to tell you that he'll be here as soon as he can. And that he loves you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby looks up to see The Postman standing at her door. She looks at him, smiling with tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mail's slow.   I'll have to see about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby smiles down at the child in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your daughter.     Her name is Hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Postman takes the tiny child in his arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so my father returned home after the Holnists were defeated...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beach town. No wall, no sentries, just cottages lining a dozen sand-swept streets. A crowd has gathered to hear The Postman's daughter, HOPE, mid-thirties, speak. Beside her, a bearded, 52-year-old Ford in his postmaster's uniform. They stand before a large, tarp-draped statue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he never did see St. Rose. There was too much to be done. He'd made a promise and in keeping it -- he traded one dream for another. With no regrets. And so, in honor of my father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She unveils the statue: we've seen this before. It's The Postman on his horse, low-slung in the saddle, leaning down to pluck the letter from the Little Boy's hand. There's an OLDER MAN in the audience who seems especially moved by the statue. There's a younger man beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As St. Rose applauds...
